Overall, ok food.  Like all the other reviews, i agree that this is a pretty clean place for a burrito/taco place.  Not much seating.  Ingredients taste fresh.  The only beef that I have w/ this place is that all their meat tastes the same.  They use this sauce to marinate them so that when it comes out, it's all red and oily.  It's not a bad sauce, but the burrito tastes like that, the nachos and quesadilla tastes like that so after awhile, everything started to taste the same.  I don't think I'll come back here.  If I want a burrito, I'll just head to Farolito.
author: AhLin C.

description:
Eh...

Meh...

Bleh...

This is mediocre Mexican food for white folks in the Mission who are scared off of going to more legit joints.  One star for the carne asada quesadilla (but who can muck that up, really?) and half a star apiece for being a super-cute clean place with outside seating and easy street parking.
author: Pink ..

description:
I really wanted to like this place because it's very nice visually.  Unfortunately, the food sucks.  Sorry, there's no nice way to say it.  I had the tamales which is always chancy and once again, I realized why it's a stupid thing to do.  A tamale is meat in masa wrapped in corn husk.  Not husk laid out w/a masa patty on top, w/meat on top, w/sauce on top.  It's a combined thing.  The only positive was the meat (pork) was not dry.

My friend had the enchiladas which were dry and boring.  In fact, the whole meal was boring.  Maybe it was the time of day we went (later afternoon) but the whole thing just tasted dry and reheated.  

There is no Salsa, that stuff on the table is just red stuff, no taste, no kick, no flavor.  Really, really disappointing, and the only hot thing in the place was the busboy.
author: hanya g.

description: one of my fav mexican hot-spots! awesome veggie taco
author: Shal S.

description:
So, I was talking to a friend about how I thought I just found my new favorite Mexican restaurant.  She totally interrupted me to tell me about this great Mexican restaurant she just discovered.  It didn't take long to figure out we were talking about the same place.

The ambiance is great.  I felt like I could actually be in Mexico for a minute.  It was quite unique from the typical Mission taqueria.  It felt very clean and well cared for.  Yet, the prices were totally reasonable.  I got a big ol' fish burrito for just $5.

Several varieties of hot sauce and fresh cut limes were available at each table.  It was a nice touch.  

Last but not least, the flan was amazing!!!!
author: Carolyn W.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet:

Best super burrito I have ever had for $6 and big enough portions to eat half for lunch and the rest for dinner. I'm all in.
author: Priya P.

description: I used to work right across the street and remember when it first opened. Delicious burritos, excellent tacos, and friendly staff. I always try to visit when I'm in the Bay Area.
author: Jess T.

description: This is probably the cheapest burrito in the Mission, and they definitely have some interesting combinations you don't see elsewhere, but ultimately, you can taste the lower-quality ingredients. Argh.
author: Mark A.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall prices with a comfortable and colorfully decorated seating area.  

Ordered the deluxe (guac and sour cream added) fish burrito, which was overwhelmingly rice and beans (of which the rice was fairly dry and tasteless) with a small piece of deep fried fish in the center.  May have chosen poorly, for my friend's fish tacos looked quite good, with a generous helping of pescado.

They had an impressive hot sauce selection, both in bottle and freshly prepared form, as well as a selection of pickled vegetables and tropical fruits to flavor your meal.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Just up the road from Blowfish, this is a great taqueria.  It holds about 10 people, and is owner operated.  The owner is super amable, but nervous about what will happen when the lease ends this year.

the chicken tacos were superb.  they should come with an inhalation device.
author: Tim G.

description:
I can't say I frequent the place all too much even though I work like across the street, but I can say that the service is great and the taco's are pretty freakin good.  The price is also pretty damn good.

My only problem with the place is that the burritos seem a bit on the small side.  But that is all.
author: Mike V.

description:
Definitely a winner for Mexican food.  It's chilly if you have to sit outside, though, but don't be surprised, because this place gets jamming most every night.

Very authentic food.  Totally affordable.  

Great place to grab a burrito if you're cruising the seedier side of the Mission and you're nowhere near one of them damned tasty taco trucks.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
People.  Eat the fish.  Thats all. 

Franciso will make you fish enchiladas if you ask nicely enough.
author: Nora B.

description:
As far as Mexican food goes it's pretty darned good. They do all of your usual favorites, they just do them better. :) No beer in the fridge--and no alcohol at their companion store too. But, if you're in the Mission definitely give them a shot.

Times visited: 5
author: Amy L.

description:
We dined at El Metate because my partner read it was "the Yelp guy's" favorite Mexican place. A reliable source? Apparently so! The food was EXCELLENT! 

Standouts were the nachos and the pork tamale with chili verde. The nachos had a liberal application of guac, great chips, amazing chicken and beans, lots of melty cheese. Now THOSE are some nachos, baby! Next time I'll skip the lettuce (personal thing, never liked warm lettuce.) The tamale was truly unique with flavorful carnitas topped with tomatillo sauce and more melty cheese. 

Other items: flour quesadilla of the flat variety (good, but for this type of quesadilla, La Taqueria and La Palma still rule), variety of tacos (skip the fish - dry, no special sauce, not even any guac, and filled mostly with rice; others seemed to enjoy the chicken in red sauce), and agua fresca (mmm, mmm, mmm - loved the honey dew!)
author: Veronica L.

description:
The only reason I held off so long on writing my 5-star El Metate review is because I knew I'd have to eat my words about El Farolito being the best taqueria in town.  Now, I still adore Farolito; their hours are ridiculous (-ly awesome) and their tacos are glorious.  But the truth is, El Metate serves up the tastiest burrito in SF.

It's cheap and so, so flavorful; in addition to the expected ingredients, they add seasonsed veggies, which I'd never really cared for in the past but which really make the Metate burrito spectacular.  And although this place closes early relative to the other Mission taquerias (10:00), the cleanliness and quaint atmosphere make for a more pleasant overall experience.

I live in the Sunset and eat here twice a week.
author: Karin H.

description:
Heaven on a tortilla.  Take two fish tacos and call me in the morning.

Oh and watermelon or strawberry aguas frescas; mix one with horchata. Warmest sweetest people behind the counter.  Go.
author: sean s.

description: Went here last night with a group of folks and enjoyed the food very much.  I ordered first and got the fish taco plate. I saw so many tasty looking photos on Yelp of this dish which is why I went with it. Came on a HUGE plate, seriously like 20" in diameter. The owner/manager is a super nice big guy who brought the food out to our table. The atmosphere was cool, and they had a large assortment of hot sauces on the wall. Fish was nicely battered and fresh tasting. Rice and beans were also very good. There wasn't anything left on my plate, I even ate half of one of my wife's chicken flautas. Will definitely come here again! Parking wasnt terrible, circled the block once and found a spot at 630pm.
author: Ryan D.

description:
mediocre, especially for its location deep in the mission, and even worse when I think of all the good spots I passed on the way there.  decor is weird too.
the burrito was put together sloppily, and the ingredients weren't stellar.
no idea what the fuss is about.
author: Christian W.

description: Ok, so we don't know SF & were in town for my son's soccer match.  We went in thinking we were getting the "real deal" as some other yelper posted....uh not! Service is great.....that get's4 stars but the food is barely a 1. I got the pozole which is a weekend special. Tasted like 1/2 homemade & 1/2 canned......ewww. I had indigestion all day & I rarely get indigestion! My daughter had 2 tacos: carnitas & al pastor. She didn't like the al pastor...nor did I when I tried it.  Carnitas were ok.  Hubby ordered a torta which was mediocre with the tasteless al pastor.  Folks unless you have had a REAL torta from Guadalajara or Mexico City, this is NOT the "real deal".  Son ordered a burrito which was ok, but again he made the mistake of ordering the tasteless al pastor.  They do have some aguas frescas which were yummy.  The salsa bar consists of a few straight from a can/bottle salsas laid out with the fruit salad salsa....the fruit salad salsa was the highlight of our meal. That & the aguas frescas.  I will not be back, we did walk around after our "meal" and saw Tortas Gordas around the corner. Will have to try them next time we are in SF.
author: Rebeca G.

description:
The burritos and quesadillas at Metate are my favorite in the Mission. I always have with the black beans. It's in a homemade style, a family run affair.  The owner, Francisco, is really friendly and keeps a great atmosphere. And the chips are delicious.

Don't be fooled, it's not as small as it looks - they have a beautiful space in the back if you want to dine in.
author: Luke S.

description: This place is great! Great price! I had the Grilled Chicken Burrito and a Fish Taco! It is the absolute best. Super CHILL spot to hang out after a bike ride. Outdoor/indoor seating, they serve to you too [tip them]! 5 Stars, must try this place if you are into Mexican Food!
author: Jonathan L.

description: The shrimp burrito and fish torta are absolutely delicious.
author: Courtney J.

description:
Like this place needs yet another positive review.

El Metate is my kitchen away from my kitchen.  When they closed in honor of immigrant's rights, it threw my world into confusion.

They have the best veggie burritos/tacos, pinto beans, pollo con chile rojo, chicken mole, fish tacos, carnitas, rice; the friendliest owner; the warmest & most inviting space of any tacqueria.

Ask for one of the special salsas too -- they always have a couple of treats tucked away.  Last time it was chipotle salsa rojas, yum.
author: Phill W.

description:
Best Mexican food I have found in SF so far!
Great Carnitas and Carne Asada!
Tortas are GREAT at the market next door (on the corner).
Highly recommend this place.
author: Matt V.

description:
My fish taco (breaded) and chicken taco were cheap and yummy but not spectacular. I liked the cheerful decor and outside seating.  

The chicken tacos at Taqueria San Francisco and La Taqueria are superior!  

I'd go back but I don't understand the hype.
author: Liz H.

description:
I truly want to love El Metate, partially because it so close to my apartment but also their burritos are actually manageable.

My first visit was of so perfect. The chicken burrito was just perfectly moist and the right ratio of ingredients. And my pineapple agua fresca washed it all down. The salsa for the chips is also precisely spiced (not too mild but not too hot).

But on my second visit, in hopes of a repeat, I was left with a fairly dried out over riced burrito.

Alas, I will give it a try again.
author: Bryan H.

description:
The experience of consuming a good burrito is one I think many can appreciate, even if it's not authentic "Mexican" fare.  Whatever, that said, a good burrito is a standard of measure for any Mexican restaurant in the city, and El Metate passes with high marks, although not top of its class.

The standard choice of meats-carne asada, carnitas, pastor, pollo, and in particular the freshly fried fish, provides the basis for whatever vehicle of consumption you can choose, from burritos, tacos, quesadillas, and platillos.  But what distinguishes El Metate from the middle of the pack is their slow cooked items, including chile colorado and carne verde, que sabroso.

At its core, is El Metate a better Mexican food spot than Papalote, Pancho Villa, or even El Farolito?  Probably not, IMO, but it is a good 2nd choice.  Bonus points include the large and airy dining area, its location next door to La Tiendita, a quaint and small little mercado, and its well placed location that offers a viable option if you don't want to wander too far into the Mish.
author: Michael P.

description:
Try the shrimp burritos. The only problem with them is that they are made with so much love that you will never order anything else from here.

I am extremely picky about shrimp, and their shrimp has never been even the slightest bit off (are you listening, every Thai food place in SF?).

I know white people hate being in a place only catered to by other white people, and this is the whitest-clientele of any Mexican place on earth, but I still love this place (see http://stuffwhitepeoplelike.com/2008/02/20/71-being-the-only-white-person-around/).

Even when there is a line out front it moves pretty quick and the order is ready without much of a wait at all. 

The prices are very good as well, considering the freshness of ingredients, the volume, and the love involved.

Go now!
author: Phil W.

description:
Good place to go for a satisfying but not-quite-coma-inducing lunch (that's a good thing), with adequate outdoor (sidewalk) seating. My favorite is the carnitas burrito.

They get dinged a star:

 * Undersupply of hot sauce. There is a little wall-shelf of stuff, but the two I grabbed were mostly empty and not spicy at all. Kudos for not copping out with the Tabasco, but even that would have been better than what was on hand. They need to carry some variety of the harder-to-find habanero and chile sauces.
 * No Dos Equis, Negro Modelo, or even Corona or Tecate (actually, no booze at all). ¿Qué carajo?
author: Rob T.

description:
I was in San Francisco for only a week, and I HAD to go back to this place. 

Fish tacos are dreamy, and the restaurant is the size of a city block. There was some construction while we there there and the owner sheepishly informed all of us that there would be some noise. 

I had zero issues with the food. I love you Metate.
author: daniel m.

description: Tasty and inexpensive. Had the tostada salad which was huge and good quality for under $6. Protip - Ask for 1/2 and 1/2 of the agua frescas. You can come up with some great combos.
author: aaron f.

description:
The owner, Francisco, is one of the kindest restaurant owners in the business.   He can be shy to approach customers at times (as he knows you want to eat his delicious food!) - but make the effort to greet him and say hello.  He is a true community focused owner.

The food?  Excellent.   I highly recommend their shrimp quesadillas.  The shrimp is  not microwaved from being frozen - always sauteed in preparation, which makes it that much more delicious.  

If you like burritos - the Chicken chili rojo is out of this world.

Their prices are excellent and the space is beautiful.  It could use more consistent cleaning, but they are quite busy.

Ask them about catering a party for you - not sure if they publicize it - but they made amazing plates of burritos for a party I went to.

Advice - if you know you are getting take out - call ahead - almost always 12 minutes on the dot.
author: Jon S.

description: Went here for the first time the other night and I must say it was pretty tasty. I had the cheese enchiladas and also decided to try one of their fish tacos. The enchiladas were good.. nothing to write home about but they weren't bad. The fish taco was really good though.. especially with some of their cucumber salsa on it. I would definitely go back for more!
author: Kristin P.

description: I was so happy to see a review of El Metate on Check Please Bay Area.  It's been one of those gems that is off the beaten path.  I haven't had a single item that wasn't solid.  The other is usually there and so very friendly.  They have a very nice dining room and a few outdoor seats.  Just hop in, place your order and roll over to the dining room on the other side.  They will bring your food to you super fast and always perfect.
author: Carl C.

description: I love love love their beef enchiladas. The red sauce is tasty but not too spicy and I the care asada filling is yummy. This place is kinda small so takeout , because their isn't much room inside or outside. I haven't tried much else on the menu since the enchiladas were a home-run but its worth going here just for those.
author: Lettie M.

description: Super bean+cheese is awesome. So is the al pastor burrito. After eating here every week for several months, other burritos in SF have a hard time living up to the gold standard set at El Metate. For a special treat, ask for the green salsa and the flour chips, rather than the corn chips and red salsa that come standard. Oh Metate, how I miss our dinner dates--don't worry, I'll still make the trek across the 'hood to visit.
author: annie s.

description: This is not a Chipotle or a raggedy taqueria on Mission Street. This is a family owned restaurant with authentic mexican cooking. The food is fresh and delicious. They have a different system where you order at the front, and seat yourself. The food is brought to you. I ordered carne asada tacos. The meat was marinated perfectly; not drenched in oil. The agua frescas were good. The salsa...oh yea this is good. The tortilla chips are homemade. The tortillas are homemade. Put it this way, I felt like I was in a little town in Jalisco. The decor is adorable...everything is colorful. I know that's not important, but the important thing is that it is clean and the cooking is delicious!! Love it!
author: Miss P.

description: We wanted good authentic Mexican food. And we found it at El Metate! The nachos could have been dinner, but we didn't stop  there. Very inexpensive, too! We had dinner at an outside table, unfortunately the neighborhood is mostly residential and the residents had their drapes drawn.
author: Jeff L.

description: A co-worker showed this place to me some years ago as it was close to work, good food for a weekday lunch.
author: Roman I.

description:
It's hard for me to rate fish tacos fairly since I've recently spent some time in Kauii. Even so...the fish tacos here are DAMN GOOD! The fish was breaded and fried, but it was not heavy or greasy. The cheese, lettuce, and salsa were extremely fresh and refreshing. The squeeze of lime brought out all the flavors of the ingredients. The only thing that threw me off was the rice. I'm not used to rice in fish tacos and I can't say that I like it. There were several bites in which I only got rice. Perhaps increasing the fish to rice ratio would make a better taco.
The carnitas torta mexicano was also delicious. The carnitas was moist, tender, and flavorful. The combination of refried beans, lettuce, tomato, red onion, avacado, jalapeno, and mayo gave the torta a wide range of flavors and somehow came together nicely. The torta also came with a side of tortilla soup. The soup was pretty flavorful, with generous portions of vegetables. The chicken in the soup was soft and tender. The tortillas were soaked in the soup, but still managed to add a crunchy texture to each bite.
El Metate offers fresh and delicious food at very affordable prices. The fish tacos aren't quite like I had in Kauii, but they are cheaper and more convenient, since I don't need a plane ticket to get them!
author: Siao W.

description:
I ordered a chicken burrito and received a giant log of goodness wrapped in aluminum foil. I've ordered this twice and couldn't finish it either time.

My girlfriend lives in the Mission District and I could spit from her front stoop and hit 30 burrito joints. I've never been disappointed by any. What makes this place better or worse than any other? Probably nothing.
author: Robert V.

description:
I remember this place when it was Mr. Sandoval's neighborhood carneceria, complete with pighead in the display case. That's when burly working men would order burritos fat with meat and beans and nothing else. 
The folks at El Metate have done a lot with the space. I was resistant at first but I love their mole plates and nacho plates. My only complaint is that when they opened up their new tienda next door, they should have switched places so they can seat more than 6, which gets a little uncomfortable when there a line. They're a super nice crew, good food, great price. Just solid. If you are getting takeout, call ahead. 
However, I'm still on the quest for the perfect chile relleno outside of New mexico.
author: Juliette T.

description:
Clean and bright, with friendly folks and a menu of mexican cuisine basics. I've been going here for a number of years and used to have dinner with my dog at one of their little sidewalk tables. Bryant is a little noisy, but it's always nice to sit outside on a sunny day. 

I had chicken nachos for lunch yesterday, which were great... I ate the entire plate. When leaving, I spied a few people eating burritos, which I've had before, and which are great, and which made me hungry again. I actually did think about going back for dinner so I could have a burrito... didn't have the chance, but I will, soon.
author: dana l.

description:
I love the burritos at El Metates but the secret is the chicken tortilla soup and Tortas. You can't order them from the restaurant section you have to go into the corner El Metate corner shop on the same block and order them there. 

The owner is a super guy and always wears a smile. I was happy to see he finally expanded the restaurant portion, it seems like El Metates takes up about half a block now!
author: patrick b.

description:
Great burrito: under $5

Delicious Agua Fresca: dirt cheap

Seeing a friend sweat buckets and shake in a total Habanero high after swallowing a teaspoon full of El Campesino Salsa Ultra Picante: priceless


(PS: I do advise reading the fine print on the bottles before going nuts with the contents of those salsa racks....)
author: Tatjana G.

description:
As I was lounging in my apartment post late-night-drunk-munchies binge (from one of the many taquerias that are open late night), I declared to my roommate the same thing I always say, stewing in self-disgust: "I am never eating Mexican food again."

Which is, of course, a total lie, as I will probably end up going to El Metate for dinner tonight because it's one of the few Mexican places in the Mission that actually provides a little variety. The burritos are the perfect size, filled with quality ingredients and you don't feel like a slob after eating them. This place is a great choice for veggies, as you can pretty much get anything on the menu by substituting seasonal vegetables for meat.

My personal favorite are the veggie nachos, which have just the right amount of other "stuff" (aside from cheese), to provide some good flavors and textures.

Now back to being hungover...
author: Victor W.

description:
I love El Metate.

They serve THE BEST vegetarian burrito in San Francisco.

Believe that.
author: Geoff C.

description:
Seafood this, shrimp that, fish whatever. I tried the nachos. That's my benchmark. The chips were great, and as they should be. The chips are the foundation, literally and figuratively, of all nachos. Too bad they built a crappy house on the foundation.

I'll go back for the seafood sometime. But man, if you can't get a good plate of nachos....
author: Matt L.

description:
El Metate came recommended and I wanted to love it, but I couldn't. The fish tacos were breaded and tasteless, not batter fried with white sauce and cabbage, as it should be (oh SF, why can't you deliver me a real fish taco). The burrito, while large and cheap, with reasonable reasonable carnitas, wasn't worth getting excited about. And no salsa bar -- just a single serving of what I'd deem more taco sauce than salsa.

The good? Clean, plenty of seating, and delicious chips.
author: Chad T.

description: Group of 6 - two people raved about their food, the rest of us looked around trying to pretend our food was as good.  I had the fish tacos and never excite me when they come out battered - usually means frozen fish.  They didn't have much flavor either - no salsa or coleslaw topping like most killer fish tacos in san francisco.  I have to be honest, I rate my mexican joints by the guacamole and veggie/fish tacos.  Neither scored better than a 1.5.  The guacamole was heavily mixed with mayo or sour cream.  The carnitas burrito was dry.  They were nice but sorry - too many wonderful mexican food establishments in this great city to be considered a good restaurant.
author: Jessica M.

description: So yummy! Chips are great, nice salsa bar, burrito was yummy. Good ambiance as well & nice staff!
author: Jenna K.

description: something about the chicken at this place is just fantastic.  must be the seasoning they use.  I also like the fish tacos which are just the right size.  friendly staff, easy parking, great crowd.
author: Reg H.

description:
This is my favorite mexican restaurant in the mission. I love the veggie burrito and the people here are so nice. 

Plenty of space, lovely decor, outdoor seating is nice. I just wish people would recycle their plastic water cups. They're just as recyclable as bottles and cans people!!!
author: madame r.

description: I go here instead of Papalote because it's more low key.  Too bad the outdoor seating is on the side of the street away from the sun or it'd be nicer when it's hot out.  The androgynous person behind the counter was very excited that they would be on "Check Please, Bay Area".  Unforch, I missed the airing of it.  The salsa is just ok is the only reason I don't give this place 4 stars.  The carnitas burrito.  OMG.  To die for.
author: aleks k.

description:
I am always searching for the fish tacos I had in Baja.
Here, they are what I remember: one long piece of fried fish in a taco topped with chopped tomato and lettuce. Plain, simple, and absolutely delicious.
One of my fav taco joints in the mission. (Papalote is the other)
I just wish they had a variety of salsa as well... but I could have missed it...
also: no beer :(
Ample seating inside and out. Clean. Pleasant on the wallet.
author: Maria L.

description:
Of all the inconsistencies, and personality conflicts, and some of the employed ingredients not being of the most exalted construction.....this place has heart. I can't describe why this explanation beckons my judgement, maybe its the claustrophobia experienced within and the hard working staff adorned in sweeping passion and company t shirts, but i felt the stamp of pulchritude as i narrowly avoided disfiguring a hipsters face on the way inside.

I purchased a veggie taco. 2 dollars, tax included. And off to work they go....... beans, wonderfully flavored rice, bliss-textured asparagus, zucchini and carrots, a cloak of cilantro (poco saboya.....dios malcidion!)  sufficient salsa, two tortilla's, a half a plate of a tres tortilla sensation, with different flavors and crunch-factor aspects. The zest was static, children. 

Next time im getting a prescription at the general ( crackheads have great abs! SHOW AND TELL TIME!) i will unload a pit stop. 

GLEFTON TOLD YOU.
author: Christopher J.

description:
On a good day (usually when Francisco is splitting time in-between here and La Tiendita), El Metate serves the best tacos ever. Even though they are now double the price of when I started going there ($1.25 in 2002, $2.50 now), the carnitas, chile verde, and pollo con chile rojo tacos are so worth it.

Francisco will not sell items that don't meet his personal standards of quality; in the old days, I have seen him give hell to an employee who tried to cut corners.  When Francisco's not around, the pork or chicken might not have been marinated quite as long as you would wish, or the carnitas might have gone a hair over the line between crispy and dry.  But, such calamities only surface rarely.

Day in, day out, El Metate is my go-to taqueria.
author: J P.

description: Now this is classic Motrero: quiet, mostly residential streets with a vibrant Mexican eatery on the corner.  El Metate is counter-ordering, but its adorable dining room is decked to the nines with bright yellow and blue artwork that rivals any yuppie beach town sit-down Mexi-cafe.  Maria D calls it stuffwhitepeoplelike, I say it's the place that Papalote wishes it was (same diff, I know).  Famous for their fish tacos, which are enormous and wrapped in double tortillas.  Deliciously fresh but not a strong fish flavor.  My arithme-taco is not so good when I'm hungry, so I botched my chance to try some of the chili verde pork...next time, I guess.
author: Wes M.

description:
5 stars for restaurant atmosphere, price, efficiency, and layout of dining room. Okay, but in terms of the food. We are talking about food here, right people? MEXICAN food?? I think probably got the wrong thing which was a veggie quesadilla. But seriously, there's many ways to elaborate on a veggie quesadilla rather than just stuffing carrots and a piece of broccoli in between two tortillas and cheese and calling it a day. I was also disappointed at the very few tortilla chips they gave. The boo got a burrito, which he said could be summed up as a classy Taco Bell burrito, meaning that it tasted like the kind of plain meat and cheesiness that their burritos always taste like, except with better quality meat. But, that's not a BAD thing, you say?? Well, I say, when a place that seems to be rated incredibly high by my fellow yelpers turns out to be a disappointment........perhaps I'm the foolish one. 

But no, I'm sticking to my guns, and sticking to the very heart and SOUL of the mission district for my Mexican food fixes.
author: Emiko T.

description:
There is nothing on this menu that doesn't deserve 5 stars.  Metate definetely has my favorite quesadilla anywhere on Earth, even including the ones I've eaten in Mexico.  The fish tacos are light and tasty.  
They've expanded into a larger dining room in the last few years, and have been able to keep up service wise.  This is great, because the line can go out the door.  
When hunting for fresh, impeccable mexican food in the Mission, think Metate!
author: Tatiana R.

description:
looking for a fish burrito under $7? want it FRIED? get it here.

FISH BURRITOS!!!! fish = spiced batter and fried. they give you a pretty generous amount, too.
refried beans = chunky and spicy
guac = chunky and everywhere
sour cream = just the right amount
NOM NOM NOM NOM NOM...

festive yellow decor, out-door seating, SPICY salsa (various options available), and free chips. make sure you go to the smaller El Metate (to the left of the main, larger restaurant).
author: Pris C.

description:
Found this place totally by accident a few weeks back.  It was a Hot day in October...yes October and I was in the Mission running errands.  Found a parking space in front of this place on Bryant Street, and 22nd?.  I was going to walk a few blocks to my destination.  Saw 15 people or so sitting outside this place eating and it looked nice.  I went in and the order counter was nothing to look at.  Took a look further into this place and wow what a nice dining room.  I stayed figuring if there are this many people here on a Tuesday at 2:30 it must be halfway decent.  I met the owner Francisco Hernandez, very nice guy...everyone seems to know him and he knows most of the customers by name...another good sign...I asked what he recommended.  This day he recommended the fish taco...so what the heck...I have an order  ...it was superb...not over breaded, not greasy, and the right amount of sauce on it...
Didn't have time for anything else but did go back two days later and tried an order of the quesadillas and a carnitas burrito.  The Burrito was good, just a bit on the dry side, but hey...they have salsas and sauces to add to it...
Definitely a go to place in the mission for me now...and the prices can't be beat.
author: Jim R.

description: The food here is consistently good.  I usually get the super grilled chicken burrito($6) and an horchata, both of which are super satisfying and doesn't break my college student bank!  The carnitas burrito and the super nachos are also delicious.  My sis loves the super chile verde burrito!  The staff is very friendly and food prep is relatively fast.  I live a block away, so its perfect for when I'm starving after a 12 hr shift and don't feel like cooking!  OH, and the flan is the best I've had, EVER.  Try it!
author: Lesliegh H.

description: Damn straight these guys got good Mexican food!  I usually go to El Farrolitos for burritos but these guys are legit as well.  Their grilled steak and chicken taste fresher than most.  Like it hasn't been sitting in a heated tray all day.  Cool spot too, more authentic than the chain Mexican joints.  Good shit Metate.
author: Ramon L.

description: I live across this place, and damn, I'm just going to say that El Farlito doesn't have shit on this place. The owner is the coolest guy, always friendly and cheery. The fish tacos are probably the best I've had in a while, and everything just tastes so fresh with a home cooked feel, in comparison to the overly greased up shit that you often find elsewhere. The interior is pretty cute, there's seating inside and out, and the service is always top notch (even though you really don't require much of it). Horchata and fruit juices are so damn fresh and good. This is the type of neighborhood joint that I'm glad to have around.
author: Chieh T.

description:
We have been only once and are looking forward to going back.
It's a relief to get good, down-home Mexican food in a relatively calm neighborhood if you are not in the mood to venture into the bustle of  the Mission District.  

Pluses:  
- Chile Relleno - nice and light, NOT heavy and greasy.
- Salsa/Condiment bar - refreshing choices, including melon salsa.
- Thick chips
- Supportive, sincere personnel

Other:
-The shrimp quesadilla was lackluster.

Overall, this is unarguably 5-star.
author: Anne J.

description:
This is my favorite place for vegetable burritos - not just a veggie burrito mind you (though that might be what they call them) - but vegetable burrito.  They fry up carrots, cabbage, sometimes broccoli and other vegetables and add them to your burrito.  I haven't been that impressed with any of their other food - fish tacos, chicken burritos.  The only problem with the burritos is sometimes they are too oily - they dump the frying oil in the burrito along with the vegetables.

They also have thick and very crunchy chips - the salsa is delicious but doesn't hold up well with those chips.
author: Carlos V.

description:
I live just around the corner from this place, so it's hard not to end up here when I start to get the shakes for a Burrito. The food is excellent... I'm vegetarian and I love that their veggie stuff includes a lot of fresh, still-crispy (rather than overcooked) vegetables. While this is great in and of itself, what's REALLY great is that their prices are the same or cheaper than most  burrito joints in this hood. They could totally charge more and I would probably pay it... but they don't!

The only complaint I have about this place is the outdoor lighting. Sometimes on a nice night it's totally excellent to sit at one of the outside tables and just hang with the bikes and dogs that people leave outside while they're picking up orders. At least, it would be nice, if they didn't have this totally random motion-sensing security floodlight aimed at the tables closest to the door. Sitting becomes this totally stressful attempt to eat a burrito while NOT MOVING or at least moving at a slow enough rate that the light won't get triggered. But suddenly you get carried away gesturing in conversation, or want to shift position in your seat, and this  halogen light blasts on, totally harshing your sidewalk-burrito-eating mellow!
author: Neale S.

description:
Given all the other reviews here - it isn't really necessary to write much!  El Metate is only a few blocks from where I live, and I find myself coming here all the time for a good, quick and inexpensive meal.  I am picky when it comes to Mexican food, but this place always meets or exceeds my expectations.  Also, the cashier is always there working and is great to talk to and joke around with.

Just watch out for the long lines!  Well worth the wait.
author: Ryan K.

description:
The best breaded fish taco on this side of the planet! Hands down! 

I've visited this place at least three times this week. The funniest part about that is I'm on a diet. The even funnier part is that it's actually working! It could have to do with the crunches, the yoga and the pilates but I'm just going to pretend it has everything to do with the elite perfection of El Metate's breaded fish masterpiece of a taco! 

I get mine with lettuce, cheese, rice and refried beans. It doesn't come with beans but you may want to fork out the extra .50 cents because it really adds to what is already perfect. 

And talk about an A for Atmosphere! You could have a wedding reception at this place. Forget that, you could have the entire ceremony at El Metate. It's romantic, warm and festive! 

See you tomorrow, El Metate!
author: Chantelle T.

description: Loved this place. Tried the burrito, tacos and enchiladas. All top notch! Can't wait to go back.
author: Nicole A.

description: I like variety in restaurants, but I end up eating at El Metate every week. Fabulous! Don't miss the flan!
author: Rob M.

description: Decent food.  Nothing like the El Metate in San Carlos though! (The two are unrelated)
author: Andrew N.

description:
The TORTA's are SO.....Good

My fav is the carnita's... It also comes with a home made chicken soup.

I usually split the sandwich cause it is really big....

This place is BIG on taste.

By the ways... the sandwich is all but 5 bucks and change
author: Torres B.

description:
there are many reasons to love metate.  a lot of people go there for their fresh and delicious food.  i am crazy about the fish tacos and pork w chile verdas sauce!  they've got a really good aqua fresca thing going on with at least 6 different flavors.  just ask them which is the best that day and they'll tell you whats good.

they recently extended their salsa to a salsa bar!  and they also have lots of hot sauces to choose from.

i also love their decor and the overall dining experience there.  they are always warm and friendly regardless of how busy they get.  often you will see lines out of the door.
author: Estelle S.

description: I'm hooked on the Tortas and chicken soup.  Great food and incredible value.
author: John P.

description:
this is as good as it gets!

came here the other evening with my friend who said this was her favorite mexican restaurant in the city, so my hopes were a bit high. but she was right! we SPLIT a super burrito ($5-$6) and were so full after that. we didn't even get to touch the carnitas taco that we ordered (however, i boxed that home & ate it the next day and it was damn good!). sipped on watermelon agua fresca throughout the meal, which totally hit the spot since it was a sunny day and we had been walking all over the mission earlier. finally, we topped off the evening, each with an Alfajores. it was my first time tasting one, but what could go wrong with short bread and dulce de leche? you must try that when you visit el metate!
author: Pauline S.

description: Amazing, fresh, flavorful burritos for pretty cheap. The hot sauce bar is a plus, the chips are thick and always good. One of the best spots to eat around the Mission
author: Donnie B.

description: Excellent Mexican served on porcelain plates. Very low cost. Burritos enchiladas and tacos. Something for all.
author: kale k.

description:
Good Mexican food at a reasonable price in an attractive setting.  

I like the taco salad and the burrito colorado, but anything with carnitas or al pastor is yummy.   Stingy with the chips and the staff is not overly helpful or friendly.

Flan is some of the best I've had in the Mission.

Its not my first choice for Mexican but my go-to when friends from the 'burbs come in to town.
author: Brenda B.

description:
Tortas are sooooooooo good & I dont feel like Death after eating them.

GET THE TORTAS

Good Prices
Coke in a Glass Bottle (Pepsi too)
Easy to get in and out.
author: John F.

description: To me, this place is the gold standard for good and cheap Mexican food with an authentic feeling. The tacos (I usually order those) are really tasty. The staff is friendly and professional. And it feels very authentic. Check them out! You won't be sorry!
author: Heidi C.

description: The owner is awesome and generous, the food is delicious, they haven't raised their prices too much since they opened, and the new sitting area and salsa bar top it off.
author: Gabby G.

description:
I love this place.

I would have started a yelp account a long time ago just to review it, but the lines there are long enough, and there's never enough seating. Fortunately, we live just a couple of blocks away, and can eat on our living room floor. But now they are expanding into the old lighting store, or whatever that was next door, so I feel okay about sharing, even though everyone else already has.

I usually get the vegetarian burrito or the chile relleno plate, both are delicious. Or get a chile relleno IN your burrito. OMG.

The burritos here aren't as big as you might be used to, if you are accustomed to El Farolito, or Castillito (my former favorite veggie burrito), but they are just the right size. With the other gigantic Mission burritos, I always have to save the last third for later. Or I just eat the whole thing and regret it immediately after wards.

The only thing they don't have that the other good burrito places have is slices of fresh avocado. That really makes a good veggie burrito great.

My BF almost always gets the quesadilla suiza, and it always looks and smells soooo good. I have to recommend it on his behalf.

The owner (Pancho?), who is not at the front counter as much anymore since their tiendita opened on the corner, is super friendly. Once when I ordered a strawberry fresca and a horchata, he suggested that I combine the two - half and half. Holy crap! That is one of the best, most refreshing drinks ever. Thank god strawberry season is almost upon us again. I've tried it with the watermelon, and it wasn't the same.

Always friendly service, too.
author: Kim Q.

description:
Loooove El Metate - my friend's band played here a few weeks ago and I've been there twice since then! I had the fish tacos the first time (which were definitely good but I wasn't expecting breaded fish, so hey) but the other times I've eaten there (once dine-in and once take-out) I've gotten the veggie burrito, which has actual grilled veggies in it! And not the cheap-filler onions & peppers (which don't work for me) but zucchini, carrots, broccoli and I can't remember what else. So so so good, fresh-tasting, great prices, nice people and just-the-right sized burrito. And I had the strawberry agua fresca last time I was there - yum! I'm craving it as I write this.

My boyfriend had the vegetarian nachos the first time and said they were the best nachos he'd ever had (I didn't even get a chance to try them before they were gone) and since then he's been a fan of the bean and cheese burrito, and when you eat there, they have two racks of assorted hot sauces so you can try them all with your burrito. 

So yes, I'm in love with this place.
author: Liz B.

description:
Was in the area for a weekend crash course. Walked down the street and stumbled upon this place. Very nice, outdoor seating, and super cheap.

Ordered the carnitas burrito and a coke for $8. Super authentic, and very tasty.

Great place.
author: B B.

description:
This is a review about a food-poisoning experience.  

Been in the Mission District for roughly 60 years.  While waiting to meet a contractor, I stopped in to the El Metate restaurant and take out on Bryant near 22nd street.  Hadn't eaten all day, so I asked for one of the larger meals, the Del Mar which includes breaded fish, oysters and/or clams, rice and vegetables.  

The Tip
Wasn't wearing my glasses, but really didn't think I needed to cuz my order was take out, not dining.  So I didn't think to leave a tip.  The cashier had to show me where to sign the receipt.  

Next, the cashier asked if they had everything to make the meal.  Two cooks responded simultaneously.  Four cooks began cooking one one stove top, while another, a fifth, started cooking on the other, cooking the breaded fish filets.  I watched, but the other four cooks closed in together (I couldn't even see in between their arms.)  So I went outside to look through the window.  I first noticed one cook preparing the shelled oysters/claims/muscles.  He held the pan high up in the air.  I also noted there was very little oil in the pan:  it was as if he was touching the flame now and then, but letting the shelled fish cook high above, perhaps a foot or more above the flame.  Then another cook moved over and was positioned to block my view from the sidewalk.  After they were done, I noticed how there were exceses of rice and vegetables (usually bell peppers) piled into the styrofoam container.  The other cook, the fifth cook, never put the breaded fish into the container.  

Alarmed by the cooking methods as well as the lack of breaded fish, I surmised that this was all about not leaving a tip.  I didn't really care about pointing out to anyone that there wasn't any breaded fish, even though it was certainly cooked.  (My Kaiser physician voiced a belief he had about foods made with bread that is cooked in oil may be responsible for a diabetic condition where the oily bread blocks the cellular pores that insulin fits into, thus obstructing glucose (food energy) from nourishing those cells.  So I ignored the missing fish item(s); usually there are two, I believe.  

When I got back home, the contractor called to say he would be a half hour late.  So I sat down to have my meal--well, what was left of it.  (Again, I didn't really mind not having the breaded fish because of its possible relationship to diabeties; but I did mind them not telling me.  I figured one or more wanted to get back at me for not leaving a tip.)  

When the contractor arrived, I explained the project, and then asked him, the usual, when I could expect a bid.  I got home about 8 P.M. or so, and then began to check my emails.  By 10 P.M., I felt sick.  So I laid down.  Started to get cold, unusually cold.  In fact, it kind of felt as if my blood were leaking someplace cuz I kept getting colder and colder around the chest, shoulder, and head areas.  

Having a background in biological sciences--including anatomy, physiology, and nutrition--I let myself think this was normal, this much cold--well, because it was a big meal.  (As I understand the nutritional aspect, when you consume food(s), especially when they pass from the stomach and into the first foot or so of your small intestine, the ilium, a lot of your blood rushes to that area carrying molecules for digestion--breaking food particles into different categories and then transporting each of those particles into the blood system.)  Problem was, never have I felt so much blood go down into this digestive process:  I felt as if I was literally freezing.  If it continued, I believe I would have blacked out.  

Only, I felt a sensation just beyond the sphincter muscle between the stomach and the ilium.  The sensation was signalling me to throw up what was in my ilium at that location.  (My wife says that's impossible, to throw up any food beyond your sphincter muscle cuz that's what the sphincter muscle is for, to prevent food from backing up into the stomach.)  Well, I did, even if this is a first.  Anyway, after I coughed up a portion of a muscle, I felt better; it took me a moment, but I felt better.  

Still cold, I laid down in bed again--covers all around me and even a space heater near me.  Then I began to feel that throw up sensation again--only, it was only slight, as if it were just the left-over film of liquid around the piece of muscle or clam that I had thrown up, the act of which made me feel better.  The signals were weak, to weak for me to get up again.  But I could feel the toxic film of liquid move on down the intestine.  By the time this weak sensation was about 8 inches beyond the ilium, I dropped into sleep.  By 3 a.m., I was awake.  

I called the police to report the unusual manner in which the cooks cooked the order.  They attempted to focus on the report as if it was just a common occurence of food poisoning from toxic sea food.  You, of course, are free to derive your own interpretation.
author: Ken S.

description:
Had dinner here last night with a friend of mine and was really impressed! The place is pretty big so it can seat a lot of people both inside and out. 
I didn't have to wait too long in line to order. I ended up ordering the "tacos al pastor" with a grapefruit soda. The tacos were very inexpensive and had a lot of meat for their size. You also get a side of nacho chips and you can pick from a variety of hot sauces they have on the shelf. The decor is also very bright and cliche Mexican...but has a very homey feel to it. You can sit at these long "family-style" tables so you get a feel for the Mexican style of eating with la familia.
The cashier was incredibly nice, making all sorts of suggestions and comments about their food. Considering the amount of people that were eating there, I didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes for the food to be brought to my table. I will definitely be coming back soon.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Amazing chile verde tacos (a little pricey now).

Also, the best veggie burritos and tacos. 5 bucks for the veggie burrito. Want a pork burrito instead? 5 bucks. Want chicken AND veggies? 5 bucks. Chicken, veggie, black beans, no rice? 5 bucks, and friggin' delicious.
author: Matt F.

description: El Metate is great if you want street style tacos but are weirded out by the questionable sanity of taco trucks. If it's a nice day out you can sit outside.
author: Jessica B.

description: update: chicken burrito was delicious. so maybe don't get vegetarian fare here. chips were also not stale this time. hooray!
author: Richa A.

description:
So Bill had this great idea for a taco tour of the mission.  The plan was to start early, two-ish, on a Saturday and alternate between tacos and drinks until we all ended up in the hospital...or the gutter.  Admittedly, this was a high-class, can't fail idea which I was wishing I'd thought of myself.  We got somewhat delayed by the weather which, being the second day of Spring, pretty much demanded that we lounge about Dolores Park with the all the other Missionites for most of the afternoon.  Just for the record, no, we did not bring our johnny-come-lately-looks-good-but-i-don't-know -how-to-ride-it fixed gears and no, we didn't feel smug drinking Tecate tallboys in paper bags...come on folks, think outside the hipster box for once, you cowards.

Where was I?  Ok, yeah, tacos.  By the time we got around to the abridged taco tour, we randomly settled on 3 places, and we might have hit more if El Metate hadn't ended the tour on such a high note.  I will only say this about the chile verde pork tacos...

...sorry, I got nuthin'.  I've a sore throat and I'm kinda tired so words are failing.  But they were good.  Man, they were good.  They've been haunting my dreams good.  The pork is perfectly juicy, tender, and  flavorful.  There wasn't a lot of talking at the table, just a lot of head-shaking, nodding, ecstatic grimaces, and pointing at our plates.  The fish tacos were also great, as were the chips and salsa.  Many hot sauces to chose from as well.  The service was prompt and very friendly and fun.  Nice, colorful back room to eat in.  There was also some incredible music playing...somewhat typical tacqueria pop run thru a psych-rock, effects-laden filter.  At least, I'm pretty sure that's what I was hearing...
author: Peter L.

description:
This place has the best vegetarian burritos in the city. 

Freshly grilled, al dente, perfectly seasoned veggies wrapped up with standard burrito fare (rice and black beans plus guac/sour cream/cheese for a buck or so more) equaled a sa-tis-fiiied belly. 

Minus a star cause the salsa was a bit too watery for my liking, and they don't serve booze. They do, however, have quite the array of hot sauce...
author: b g.

description: I checked out this place after reading reviews here. I like the decor, a good place for groups of 8 people. They also have a few tables outside. A quiet, relaxing place to eat in a sunny day. The food is decent, has big portion. But I was slightly disappointed. I expected a bit higher quality based on the reviews I read here. But rating is so relative. I will go back there if I happen to look for a Mexican restaurant in that area.
author: Weilun C.

description: Yeah, you can hit a Mexican place in the Mission on every corner but this place is the best.  I mean really.  They make veggie stuff with real veggies and the veggie burritos are slammin'.  They recently expanded so now it's big and you can sit down.
author: molly m.

description: I love El Metate and there's really only one reason why...the super shrimp burrito! This burrito has yet to disappoint, pretty consistent. I've tried a few other things from the menu (all the tacos, quesadilla) and they are just okay, but the super shrimp burrito is bomb. They use large shrimp and a good amount of them. I do wish they had a separate line or something for pick-up orders, but I guess my favorite shrimp burrito in SF so far is worth the wait.
author: chloe h.

description: i am giving 3 stars just because their tortilla chips weren't that great and those free chips can tell a lot about any mexican place, quesadilla was good though, and the steak taco wasnt bad but had better, will give it another chance though it looks nice clean
author: NAEL K.

description: Best Burrito in town. nuf said.
author: Katie C.

description: the fish taco platter and agua fresca were great!
author: Samantha C.

description: Thanks Yelp, This was the best fish taco I have ever had and my partners Cheese Enchiladas weer amazing.  I searched for Fish tacos and boy did you deliver.
author: Matthew S.

description: I admit, I'm a little embarrassed to write that I'm pretty positive that the owners and employees of El Metate known us. I think before he left, one of the old workers knew just about my whole life story and we were on a "hey do you want to come to this party later" basis. All of the guys of El Metate are super duper friendly, fast, and just, well, super duper friendly. The owner is in there all the time and confessed to working his butt of to make sure his restaurant remains the best around. It absolutely pays off...I just wish they had some sort of buy 20 burritos get one half off. Something to ease our household El Metat-addiction.
author: Nicole d.

description: I had the BEST tacos de Bistec. Im from Mexico city, so i know a good taco when i eat one :) the beef was so lean and had very good seasoning. they have a huge selection on their menu. they also have BYOB how cool is that?! If you are one of those people that has to "disect" the meat in their taco, here u can just foggedaboutit~! yes the beef is that lean, and that good. YOU GOTTA GO!
author: L V.

description: Heavenly burritos. For vegetarians, most places don't have great burrito options but El Metate has an amazing veggie mix (broccoli, carrots, etc) in addition to great rice/beans/etc. Pretty hilarious cash register guy too.
author: E T.

description: OOOOhhhh baby!  I read these reviews, and decided to give it a shot. Well worth it! this is the best mexican food I've had in all of San Francisco. (Not a statement to be taken lightly).  Tasty burritos (not all wet and drippy), however I was caught off guard by the carrot. (Next time I'll order my burrito sans carrot)  Katie B. had it right, I ordered the chile verde nachos, and I nearly died trying to stuff just one more bite down my throat.  Also, SUPER cheap!
author: Dan M.

description: el metate is one of my very favourite taquerias in a world full of deliciously fabulous taquerias. the veggie burritos have Broccoli in them, the chips to go are served in yellow origami wrapping, cutie guy at the register is so kind, and the fresh fruit juices are the best.
author: aerin w.

description:
the difference between this place and other taquerias is the ambiance.

on a sunny weekday, you can walk past the beautifully painted mural of the nearby school on this relatively quiet block with only the sounds of playing schoolchildren in your ears.

i got a taco plate (2 tacos, rice, beans, guac, lettuce) for $6.75.  the pastor was a little greasy and salty, but very flavorful, and the carnitas was also tasty but a little dry.  the rice was super yummy and very fluffy.  my friends got quesadillas, which they thought were prettty good, and strawberry drinks (yummy).

we sat outside on the colorful benches and tables and had a nice workday lunch in the sun.  it was peaceful and even when the line went out the door, the place did not feel crowded at all.  

i highly recommend this place for a change of pace from all the overcrowded, loud, & sometimes dirty places in the mission where parking is impossible.  parking here is also a breeze.
author: Josie M.

description: The food really sucks and it's way expensive.........damn it...I'm just kiddin...I guess I was trying to scare off all you folks who don't live in the hood....but it hasn't worked....great food, great prices and great owner.....i just wished we could have kept this gem to ourselves....***sigh***
author: A P.

description: I could see myself coming here on a regular basis.  I only wish all great eats were as inexpensive as El Metate.  Why as humans do we feel the need to be constantly finding new restaurants when the ones we know and love can consistently provide awesomely fulfilling pleasure, value and nutrition?
author: P H I L H.

description: I'll throw my sombrero into the ring and stake a claim that El Metate is the bestest Mexican in the mission.  I've tried a bunch of them - they were either too salty or too bland, had poor quality ingredients, or blasted me with fluorescent light!  I was about to give up and take a trip to Coyoacan, D.F. when... I found El Metate.  The food is always great, the surroundings clean and attractive, takeout orders accurate and timely.  Those guys hustle - and are always courteous.
author: Dan C.

description: I come here for the fish tacos the fish tacos the fish tacos and they're fine fine fine. I never even realized that there was a huge dining room next door. My only complaint is with the guac - I feel like it's food service and not made fresh there. Other than that, Salud.
author: Mark G.

description:
el metate,
i love you.
you have the best veggie tacos (with black beans) i've ever had the privilege of tasting.  i also love your chips and salsa.  you are so clean and your cooks and servers so nice...  i wish you were closer to me.  *sigh.
unlike other places who are confused about veggie tacos and veggie burritos, this place actually understands that veggie tacos and burritos should ACTUALLY include VEGGIES other than iceburg lettuce and unripe tomatoes.  El Matate veggie tacos and burritos have ACTUAL VEGGIES in em' like sauteed broccoli, carrots, onions, cabbage, and other yummy perfectly cooked veggies and they wouldn't dare use unripe tomatoes.  thanks.
author: Emi K.

description: I must admit the yellow exterior drew me in but it's the green umbrella that keeps me coming back. Great streeturchin watching from the spacious veranda, if you luck out and get the table near the refusebin you can watch them blindly grope for tasty morsels hidden within.  It's a winwinwin situation. The food...is strange. The outer foil is light and crisp while the inner foil is moist and flavorful. The breading is fishy, faux-bark chips a nice touch for vegans, and the salsa reminds me of that stuff that comes out before the real ketchup if you don't shake thoroughly...but since this all costs less than a migrant laborer handjob($5) who am i to ...refuse
author: owl c.

description: Thank god this place is a hike from my house otherwise the super friendly staff would know my first and last name and how I like my burrito. There's a reason everyone loves this place, because it's freaking amazing. And it's unique and memorable from other taquerias with it's quaint little dining area and hot sauce rack. The burritos are fabulous and fish tacos not to be missed. The next time I visit, I'm bringing an IV so I can inject the horchata directly into my veins.
author: Michael E.

description: Sorry had to update this listing - found a dead fly in our pickled veggies and it basically killed our lunch. The best prices in town and the nicest people but it's hard to go back after that.
author: Mariangela S.

description: Simply the best Mexican food in the Mission, which by extension, could mean the whole damn country.  The veggie burritos have actual broccoli, carrots and zuchinni in them.  The quesadillas are excellent, with gooey cheese inside and oaxaca cheese on top.  Their guacamole and salsas are the best around.  And make sure to ask for the flour chips, for a real treat.  El metate is one of those places where you can tell the people who work there make a extra effort to make things really really good, and it shows. Sign the petition to save the indoor seating!
author: Ben V.

description: I might trade my boyfriend for the chiles rellenos. Strictly a pick-up place unless you want to sweat over the tamarind aguas.
author: Dana O.

description: El Metate rocks.  Finally a place where I can convince the most ridiculous La Taqueria snobs to join me.  I generally go with the quesadilla suiza or anything else with carnitas.  I'm always satisfied here.
author: Kristy K.

description:
when a coworker recommended el metate, someone asked, "what's el metate mean?"  "it means 'the metate.'" i responded to humorous effect.  "thanks a lot," was their sarcastic response, so i looked it up.  what do you know - it DOES mean "the metate!"

metate (also metate stone) noun (in Central America) a flat or slightly hollowed oblong stone on which materials such as grain and cocoa are ground using a smaller stone.

as of this writing, this is my favorite taqueria.  parking is a bitch, but it's worth going out of your way.
author: Sarah B.

description: Simply put the best Mexican restaurant in SF.  The prices are cheap even by mission standards with a fish massive fish taco running a buck and a half, and burritos at $3-4.  Horchata is only $1, which of course lead to me having three.  I have debated with myself on whether I should yelp this place at all, worried of the throngs it would bring, but the people there are so nice and friendly I can only hope that money ruins them.  Located in a residential area, you can sit outside and watch people passing in life.  Fantastic.
author: Ian H.

description: I really like the pork tacos here. Can't go wrong with any of the four (4!) pork flavors. Almost too much food if you add the rice & beans. delicious fresh chips & salsa. Nice mom type at the counter who ran next door to the store to get my sniffling friend T some green tea! T, who is a vegetarian (probably why she's sick all the time, heh) says the veggie quesadilla is the bomb.
author: J. R.

description: I feel old, I dated myself by saying seating is tight. They added on a resturant wing, so feel free to sit and enjoy your burrito, extra guacamole and horchata cupcake (yes yes i know- delicious) and feel free to stare at the hipsters that frequent the area. they like that.
author: judi p.

description: For a random Saturday night fish taco craving this spot barely did the trick. While breaded and deep fried (usually an indicator of awesomeness) the fish tacos came out a little bland. Three-and-a-half stars for the cute decor and decent carne asada.
author: Valerie C.

description: I love El Metate.  I moved to the neighborhood a year ago and the place is literally across the street.   I practice willpower and don't go as much as I would like but the food, warm ambiance and staff are all really great.   I recently ordered the pork chile verde tacos for a party of 25 and the guests devoured it in no time at all.   The prices are great, it is a family owned business celebrating six years in November and I just always know I'll have a great meal.  I even call ahead when I land from a flight to pick up a dinner I know will be great.
author: Kimberly C.

description: The place is clean, reasonably priced with good food and service.  The atmosphere is chill and you can bring a beer in from the corner store outside.  The fish tacos are supposed to be the "best," however, I prefer the fish tacos at Bender's on 19th and So. Van Ness.  This is a quality joint and they deserve three stars because they are A-OK.
author: Brianne O.

description: What can I say--this place is a Five Star Taqueria, and then some.  Particularly noteworthy are the fish tacos, fish burritos, and general good service.  Plus I hear they're opening a new torta store and tienda two storefronts over (on the corner where the unsuccessful liquor store once was--I guess nobody can compete with Jefferson Market, the best market on the block!).  So there you go.  If you want good Mexican food, that is.
author: Adam F.

description: The bottom line is El Metate has the best chile verde on earth. Trust me. I am a Jew. I know about pork products.
author: Joshua d.

description: I have heard the hype and finally found it last night. Two dollar soft tacos choice of meat, veggies, or beans. $5 dollar dinner plates that come with rice and beans. Choice of enchiladas, tacos, burritos. Salsa, guac, and sour cream, a dollar extra. Nachos are $3 bucks. Their quesadillas are the best I have had in the city. I dare anybody to challenge me on this. They use oaxaca cheese, queso fresco, and jack. I had  it with grilled veggies. Thin strips of cut carrots, zucchini, and squash. I think I just recited the whole menu so it shouldn't be too hard to decide what you want before going. Very very small setting. I reccomend getting it to go. I have to say one thing about the sauce on their enchiladas. Sooo good. Reminds me of my grandma's style back in the day. She had a bit more spice to it, but damn....It is so worth $5 bucks.
author: monika l.

description: Their veggie burritos with big pieces of sliced vegetables are delicious!  I also like their special chile relleno.
author: Jonas H.

description:
the ONLY thing to cure my campari/cheap tequila/jameson induced hangover yesterday was el metate. i rolled out of bed (at 7pm), tucked my sweats in my boots (i know, gross), and hit that shit. when i did the master cleanse for nine days, i CONSTANTLY craved el metate's coveted super veggie black bean minus guac burrito. there were always burritos floating around in the black space of my mind. 

the ONE negative point about my favorite taqueria is their seemingly from-a bag-guacamole. but who even needs that when you have fresh, al dente veggies sauteed in the most amazing buttery wine sauce, mingling with cheese (is it asadero? i dunno but it's the best cheese in any burrito in the city) and beans and the most delicious rice EVER, and sour cream? you can taste every ingredient on its own, and they all compliment each other perfectly. you don't need your food to be saturated with tallow in order to enjoy it. 

the staff is the sweetest of any taqueria that i know of, and who wouldn't want to support one of the nicest business owners in the city?
author: Elle C.

description: El Metate makes a great burrito at a reasonable price.  For $4.75, I was able to get a delicious chicken burrito with chips.  There was a perfect mixture of chicken, beans, and rice in each bite.  The burrito isn't overly greasy and relies more on the taste of well-seasoned ingredients for flavoring.
author: Josh K.

description: Nasty. Had two cheese enchiladas w/ rice and beans. The cheese in the enchiladas were not even melted. And the sauce was NOT good. served warmish.  won't ever come here again.
author: Megan M.

description: Alright, so since I have only eaten one item when I come here i'm going off of that.  I have family and friends that have tried other things here though and they said everything has been super good!  This place has the best vegetable burrito I have ever had! I always want to try something different when I go, but I just can't get myself to do it.  Anyways, this is a cool little spot.  There is plenty of room to sit and they also have outdoor seating. Know what's even better? You can bring your own beer!  ( I just read that from someone else's post)...how awesome is that?  This is definitely my go to place when I have a craving, you can't go wrong with El Metate.  Definitely worth checking out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Shannon M.

description: I was craving for a big burrito and ended up in this cozy little place. Order and then you seat yourself. I got a grilled chicken burrito (chicken, rice, beans = nothing special here). I decided not to get the guac, cheese, sour cream add on b/c I wasn't feeling guacamole that day. Bad idea, burrito was bland, but I love their hot sauce rack on each side of the restaurant. Thank you PACE salsa for making my burrito A-OK. I know, you're probably thinking, WTF, why would you use pace at a restaurant with all kinds of authentic hot sauces (I like Pace better than pico de gallo yo!). Hey, at least I didn't end up using Sarachi sauce instead (which was on the rack!).
author: Tracy T.

description: I'll never forget the first time I ate here. It was Christmastime and raining. Zoe and I ran in soaking wet with dripping umbrellas. We dried off over enchiladas at the window table covered with fake pine branches and an insanely detailed nativity scene with hot sauce bottles artistically placed around the little baby Jesus. Is it blasphemous to call a meal holy? This place is so yummy; it seems like another cheapie taqueria but those quesadillas, tacos, burritos are made con amor, my friend. Finished with lunch, we wiped our mouths and drew hearts on the steamy window pane.
author: Katrina D.

description: Increible oyes!"  This place rocks.   When you walk in its like being transported through a window in time to an old-world mexico cantina.  You may notice the aria in spanish playing in the background or the black and white photos of traditional mexican events.  If you don't, you will certainly notice the quality of the food.  Everything on the menu is requisimo!  I am a personal favorite of the fish or carnitas tacos, and occassionaly I step up to the chile rellenos or chicken flautas.  They have the occasional mole or lengua specials, but by and large they stick to the basics.  Make a point to stop by this place in the summer and enjoy the outdoor seating.  Its a different experience than the other mexican joints in the Mission (which are also good) and thankfully its right around the corner from me.  Que bueno!
author: Kevin J.

description:
despite the fact that this joint is across the street from the home of my least favorite man in the entire city, i dig it.  it has a very different feel than any of my other favored taquerias--something about the umbrellas outside and the coke in the glass bottles.  while i am normally a nachos girl, i always get their carne asada burrito beacuse it is HEAVENLY.

also, i always get a big wink when i ask for extra spicy and it makes me feel like i'm in some club for people who should have been mexican (like me).
author: calamity d.

description: I LOVE this place.  Now that they have added the extra dining room, it is my favorite taqueria in the city.  The fish is always good as are the carnitas.
author: brett b.

description: Attention ALL cheese lovers...their quesadillas are sure to please!!! when i first walked in to this quaint mexican joint, i was a bit skeptical. the place is squeaky clean and doesn't quite scream out mission quality mexican food. but little did i know i was in for a treat when i got my grilled chicken quesadilla. the chicken was cooked to perfection, juicy and tender. the cheese...OOO the cheese was definitely the star of the dish. they put a combination of cheeses that will satisfy any cheese tooth =)  this is my new found love!
author: Melissa Y.

description: Just had an incredibly delicious fish quesadilla here for lunch. The service is nice, the fish is tasty, good chips, great guac. My friend had a shrimp tacos plate, which was also delicious. The food comes out fast, and since this is in a sunnier part of the city, the outdoor seating is a nice treat. Go to El Metate for a great fish burrito/quesadilla/tacos - you will not be disappointed!
author: Jono K.

description: I've never seen a more perfectly cylindrical, smoothly wrapped, beautifully packaged burrito anywhere.  It's like an aluminum foil tube of wonderfulness.  I love what's inside, as well, in particular the carnitas and the vegetarian.  I've heard the 'tongue n cheek' is tasty but I can't go there.  I love the fact that they are really nice and that they wear their matching bright green t-shirts with a drawing of the storefront on it, and they reportedly give you reusable El Metate bags as well.  I also like the fact that it is not surrounded by similar establishments, rather, it is embedded in a residential neighborhood.  The other night I even got all flaky and couldn't make up my mind and ended up ordering wrong, (forgot to say super, for one) but I STILL loved my burrito.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Best fish tacos ever.  Get the fish taco PLATE for rice+beans and guac, for under 7 bucks.  Burritos here are marginal, it's about the tacos.  Some chef voted their Chili Verde the best in town in 7x7 (not the best barometer, but still-)

Minus one star for marginal burrito, and lack of seating (but they are expanding into the place next door, so that'll be solved soon).
author: Arlo J.

description: Oh man, two disappointments in one week...I'd skip El Metate and go straight for the taco trucks. El Matate food (the enchilada and tacos, anyway) were not nearly as flavorful and didn't look all that appetizing, either. The meat was kind of dry and and corn tortilla was way too thick. ::sigh:: At least they had my favorite flavor of Jarritos.
author: Josephine J.

description: My favorite tacqueria in SF. I drive cross town for their fish quesadilla and fish burrito. Yum!
author: Jon R.

description: Hands down the best casual taqueria in the city.  Fresh quality ingredients, good portions.  Compared to El Farolito, it's less greasy and cleaner.
author: Vik K.

description:
I have serious problems with El Metate. 1st, they cut corners every chance they get: the hot sauce has water in it, the chile verde pork has tripe in it (or something white and intestinal whatever it was), and the guacamole is basically sour cream with a dash of avocado. 2nd, why does it take 25 minutes to make a burrito out of pre-made ingredients? 3rd, Francisco, please stop talking to everybody for hours on-end when the line is out the door, keep those people moving, make that money!

PS. I added another star because they have improved their performance.
author: Ben B.

description: Try the Chicken Milanesa Tacos...Really good and something different compare to the other taqueria. The Flour chips are off the hook too. My only problem...NO COLD BEER..FML
author: Eko A.

description: $1.75 FISH TACOS!  Can't go wrong. Great little place, friendly owners and horchata for a $1 which ment, I am sooo full but I think I need one cause it is only $1!!
author: Alyssa C.

description: We hauled ass all the way here today to get the famous fish tacos, but were, unfortunately, somewhat disappointed... average at best.  I've definitely had better - in the city & elsewhere.
author: Vandana N.

description: Hijole Jesus, I can't wait to get back to the bay.
author: Adam S.

description: Tried the shrimp burritos here (which they don't always serve) and it was great!  The sauce they use with the shrimp is really flavorful but not overwhelming.  There was a good mix of beans, rice, cheese, sauce, and tortilla.  I would've preferred if there were more shrimp, but I am a little greedy when it comes to food.  I got a side of guacamole to spread on my burrito as well, but it wasn't necessary because I didn't want to mask the flavor of the sauce.
author: Robyn F.

description: Freakin awesome veggi black bean burrito, xtra good with the chipotle hot sauce straight from the bottle.  Watermelon juice is perfect, too.  Great mexican in every way.  Love the expansion into the next door space, so now lots of room to sit.  They have taken over the whole building now on that side of the block - with the kitchen, dining area, and tienda - and that's fine with me, it's very yellow and bright, fun messy mexican tromp loeil (sp?) walls.  Food is very authentic and fresh and much more than you'd expect (except the prices, great prices, very low, especially for the quality and size of what you get.)   PS: Burrito is big and perfect to split.  If you're craving a mexican escape, this is next best.
author: Today Y.

description: Francisco and David are the perfect local business owners.  One of them is always there, not that the staff need supervision.  The tacos are amazing and the burritos, although not the best I've ever had, are certainly up there in the top five.  The atmosphere is charming, warm, and friendly, as is the service.  I've never had to wait very long either, regardless of how busy they are.  I love the new dining room they just opened next door - they certainly needed the extra space.
author: Jane S.

description: another new addition to my taqueria rotation.  my husband had tried the tacos here years ago and told me it wasn't worth it.  but last year, we went again and it was so yummy.  i didn't like the fish tacos though everyone else seems to recommend them.  my favorite things here are the carnitas, bistec a la mexicana and chile relleno burritos.  the chile relleno is off menu but they usually have them around.  the alfajores here are just ok, too soft.  oh but how can i forget to mention the most delicious tortas too - i've had both the carnitas and the milanesa.  The carnitas is better but both are great and it comes with tortilla soup.  I used to share the torta and the soup with my husband for lunch and we would both be stuffed.  it is a great deal and I think only about $7.
author: a g.

description: I love this place...  I don't get all the negative reviews.  I eat there almost weekly and have never gottten sick ever.  The rice is like my grandma made.  The best in the Mission.
